column2: A person who participates in babywearing.
When the seller of a wrap asks to have the first option to buy back a wrap that they have sold. Buy Back Dibs.
column5: She has BBD on that wrap.

column2: When the seller of a wrap asks to have the first option to buy back a wrap that they have sold. Also known as BBD.
column5: She has buy back dibs on that wrap.

column2: It is achieved by taking the outer rail and bringing it toward the neck while taking the inner rail and bringing it towards the outer shoulder and arm area. This might be done to pick up slack in the fabric, to be more comfortable over the shoulder, or to move the fabric away from baby's face.
column5: The closed shoulder flip is a game changer!

column2: When a baby has a nap while touching their caregiver, usually in a baby carrier.
column5: I love when baby has a contact nap.

column2: A derogatory term for a babycarrier that does not create an ergonomic position for the baby, where baby's knees are in an "m-position" above their hips. Described as a crotch dangler as baby's legs dangle as the seat is narrow.
column5: Did you see the photos of that crotch dangler?

column2: "a wrap quality. Cushy wraps have a "marshmallow"-like quality"
column5: My favourite is when a wrap has a lot of cush.

column2: Refers to the edge, seam, or border of a carrier, typically a wrap, a ring sling, or in a pouch. The rail may typically be referred to as either the top or bottom rail or the inner or outer rail depending on the orientation of the fabric.

when you take the fabric that is sitting over your shoulder and flip it. This might be done to pick up slack in the fabric, to be more comfortable over the shoulder, or to move the fabric away from baby's face.
column5: I think I need to shoulder flip to adjust this carry.
column7: open shoulder flip, closed shoulder flip

column2: 1. A wrap that is saved for special wearing with a newborn baby; 2. Qualities making a carrier (usually a wrap) best suitable for wearing newborns or small babies, typically fabric composition (wraps) or construction (SSCs).
column5: I found the most squish-worthy carrier!

column2: 1. To pick up a child around their middle or trunk, as if they are flying like superman with their arms stretched out in front, and swing them around to your back in order to place them in a back carry. 2. Also known as "superman toss" (verb) - implying a type of loading of the baby.
column5: The superman toss makes back carries so much easier!

column2: Reverse side of the wrap. Inside of the material. This refers to woven wraps that have weaves where one side is different than the other.
column5: I know itâ€™s the wrong side of the wrap, but I love the way they final tie looks.
